<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 332, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 247, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 311, 388, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 504, 373]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 372, 892, 402]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 416]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 892, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 505]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 518, 764, 534]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 533, 467, 549]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 564, 630, 580]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>

<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 794, 92]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows an aircraft flying in a straight horizontal line at constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 101, 435, 120]]<|/det|>
\(W\) is the weight of the aircraft.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 127, 648, 146]]<|/det|>
\(L\) is the lift (upward force) due to air flow over the wings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 152, 504, 171]]<|/det|>
\(T\) is the thrust force due to the engine.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 179, 428, 198]]<|/det|>
\(D\) is the air resistance (drag).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 209, 520, 228]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the direction of these forces.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 237, 756, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 388, 510, 407]]<|/det|>
What are the relationships between the forces?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 416, 134, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 416, 292, 435]]<|/det|>
\(L = W\) and \(T = D\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 444, 133, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 444, 400, 463]]<|/det|>
\(L = W\) and \(T\) is greater than \(D\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 470, 133, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 470, 400, 489]]<|/det|>
\(L\) is greater than \(W\) and \(T = D\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 496, 133, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 496, 510, 515]]<|/det|>
\(L\) is greater than \(W\) and \(T\) is greater than \(D\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 871, 89]]<|/det|> The diagram shows an air-filled rubber toy. A child sits on the toy and its volume decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 561, 120]]<|/det|> The temperature of the air in the toy does not change. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 128, 695, 266]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 276, 567, 294]]<|/det|> How does the air pressure in the toy change and why? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 306, 707, 435]]<|/det|>
pressurereason
Adecreasesair molecules move more slowly

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows an electric heater being used to heat a beaker of water and an identical beaker containing oil. Both are heated for one minute.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 109, 675, 242]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 255, 920, 290]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the water and the temperature of the oil increase steadily. The increase in temperature of the oil is much greater than that of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 301, 220, 319]]<|/det|>
Why is this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 134, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 330, 485, 348]]<|/det|>
Oil has a higher boiling point than water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 357, 133, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 357, 477, 375]]<|/det|>
Oil has a lower boiling point than water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 383, 131, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 383, 581, 400]]<|/det|>
The oil has a larger thermal capacity than the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 408, 133, 427]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 408, 593, 426]]<|/det|>
The oil has a smaller thermal capacity than the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 452, 106, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 452, 675, 470]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the direction of a change of state is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 481, 131, 500]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 481, 524, 500]]<|/det|>
Evaporation is the reverse process to boiling.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 508, 131, 526]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 508, 581, 526]]<|/det|>
Evaporation is the reverse process to condensation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 535, 131, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 535, 531, 553]]<|/det|>
Evaporation is the reverse process to melting.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 561, 133, 580]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 561, 571, 579]]<|/det|>
Evaporation is the reverse process to solidification.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 579, 89]]<|/det|> Three cups are made from the same insulating material. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 97, 831, 300]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 310, 589, 329]]<|/det|> The cups are each filled with the same volume of hot tea. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 341, 831, 359]]<|/det|> In which cup does the tea cool most quickly and in which cup does it cool most slowly? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 370, 433, 500]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 905, 89]]<|/det|> Diagram 1 shows a wire carrying an electric current. The wire is between the poles of a magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 871, 119]]<|/det|> The current and the magnetic field produce a force on the wire which is upwards, as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 128, 866, 285]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[256, 274, 344, 293]]<|/det|> diagram 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[653, 274, 742, 293]]<|/det|> diagram 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 305, 742, 323]]<|/det|> The magnetic poles and the current are now both reversed, as in diagram 2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 336, 573, 353]]<|/det|> In which direction is the force on the wire in diagram 2? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 364, 248, 381]]<|/det|> A downwards <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 390, 134, 408]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 390, 463, 408]]<|/det|> towards the North pole of the magnet <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 415, 134, 433]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 415, 465, 433]]<|/det|> towards the South pole of the magnet <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 443, 131, 460]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 443, 227, 460]]<|/det|> upwards <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 490, 106, 508]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 489, 517, 508]]<|/det|> A nuclide of radon-222 is represented by \(^{222}_{86}\mathrm{Rn}\) . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 523, 742, 541]]<|/det|> How many protons and how many neutrons are in a nucleus of this nuclide? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 553, 432, 682]]<|/det|>

A86136
B86222
